    "for different numbers @xmath9 of _ penetrable _ spherocylinders as a function of @xmath140 for monodisperse ( dashed lines ) and bi - disperse ( solid lines ) spherocylinders .",
    "the parameters of the bi - disperse distribution are @xmath141 , @xmath29 , and @xmath142 .",
    "the monodisperse systems are generated by considering rods with identical lengths coinciding with @xmath27 .",
    "all lengths are in units of @xmath24 . in the figure",
    "the number density is fixed at @xmath143 for all cases . ]    for both penetrable and impenetrable spherocylinders we follow same the method to calculate the critical distance @xmath17 .",
    "namely , for a given number density @xmath18 of spherocylinders which are either penetrable or impenetrable with hard - core diameter @xmath8 , we coat each spherocylinder with a penetrable shell of thickness @xmath144 , and we consider two spherocylinders to be connected if their penetrable shells overlap . for penetrable systems ( i.e. , for @xmath145 )",
    "@xmath10 represents the diameter of the penetrable spherocylinder . for each realization of the system , we compute through the clustering method described in ref",
    ".  @xcite the minimum value of @xmath10 such that a cluster of connected spherocylinders spans the entire sample . by counting the number of instances that sample - spanning clusters appear for a given @xmath10",
    ", we construct the percolation probability curve @xmath146 .    as in the main text , for systems of penetrable rods",
    "we adopt as unit of length the quantity @xmath24 , which corresponds to the critical distance in the second virial approximation for monodisperse spherocylinders with length fixed at @xmath27 .",
    "examples of @xmath146 obtained from @xmath147 realizations of polydisperse ( solid lines ) and monodisperse ( dashed lines ) systems of penetrable spherocylinders are shown in fig .",
    "[ figs1 ] for different numbers @xmath9 of spherocylinders with density fixed at @xmath143 . for the polydisperse cases",
    "we have considered a bi - disperse length distribution @xmath35 with @xmath141 , @xmath29 , and the number fraction of long rods @xmath142 .",
    "the monodisperse systems were generated by spherocylinders of length equal to @xmath38 , which for the particular distribution considered corresponds to @xmath148 .",
    "figure [ figs1 ] reveals that the spanning probabilities for the bi - dispersed systems are shifted to lower values of @xmath10 when compared to the @xmath146 curves for the monodisperse case , indicating that the polydisperse systems percolate at smaller volume fractions .",
    "for both the polydisperse and the monodisperse cases the curves for the two highest values of @xmath9 intersect at approximately @xmath149 , which we take as our criterion for identifying the critical distance @xmath17 . for the particular case of fig .",
    "[ figs1 ] we find @xmath150 and @xmath151 for the monodisperse and polydisperse cases , respectively .     for different densities @xmath18 of _ impenetrable _ and bi - disperse spherocylinders as a function of @xmath152 , where @xmath8 is the hard - core diameter .",

    "our results for penetrable spherocylinders shown in figs . 1 , 2 , and 3 of the main text have been obtained by considering simulation box sizes @xmath11 such that @xmath156 , where @xmath47 is the largest rod length for any given distribution , and the number @xmath9 of particles exceeds @xmath157 .",
    "the resulting critical distances have been obtained by adopting the criterion @xmath158 .",
    "figure [ figs2 ] shows the spanning probability @xmath146 obtained from @xmath159 equilibrium configurations of bi - disperse systems of impenetrable spherocylinders with @xmath153 , @xmath154 and @xmath155 and for different values of the number density @xmath18 . from the largest to the lowest densities the number @xmath9 of spherocylinders decreases from @xmath160 to @xmath161 and the box size @xmath11 increases from @xmath162 to @xmath163 . we have used a fitting to a simple sigmoidal function to evaluate the critical distance from @xmath158 and from the mean of the distribution function @xmath164 .",
    "the two methods give values of @xmath17 which differ at most by a few percent .",
    "to avoid exceedingly large computational times , we have been careful to choose rod length distribution functions with length @xmath47 of the longest rod not exceeding about @xmath165 times that ( @xmath34 ) of the shortest one . despite of this constraint",
    ", we still have been able to generate length distributions with large scaled variances @xmath166 . among the different distributions considered , the bi - disperse one ,",
    "i.e. , @xmath35 with @xmath167 , had the largest @xmath90 for a given @xmath40 @xcite .",
    "figure  [ figs3 ] shows @xmath168 ^ 2 $ ] where @xmath169 , @xmath170 , @xmath171 , and @xmath165 as a function of @xmath28 .",
    "we see that for @xmath172 and @xmath173 , @xmath90 is well above @xmath174 .    in fig .",

    "we have used @xmath121 and @xmath122 , @xmath123 , @xmath124 , and @xmath125 .",
    "the corresponding scaled variance @xmath166 is @xmath175 . to guarantee that the ratio of lengths between the longest and shortest rods never exceeded @xmath176 , the distribution was truncated ( and subsequently normalized ) by eliminating from the sampling all spherocylinders with @xmath177 smaller than @xmath178 of the maximum of the distribution .",
    "uniform distributions of rods ( right panel of fig .",
    "[ figs4 ] ) have been constructed from @xmath126 for @xmath127 and @xmath128 otherwise , with @xmath129 and @xmath130 , @xmath131 , @xmath72 , and @xmath132 .",
    "for all cases the scaled variance is @xmath179 ."

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the connectedness percolation threshold ( @xmath0 ) and critical coordination number ( @xmath1 ) of systems of penetrable spherocylinders characterized by a length polydispersity are studied by way of monte carlo simulations for several aspect ratio distributions . </S>",
    "<S> we find that ( i ) @xmath0 is a nearly universal function of the weight - averaged aspect ratio , with an approximate inverse dependence that extends to aspect ratios that are well below the slender rod limit and ( ii ) that percolation of impenetrable spherocylinders displays a similar quasiuniversal behavior . for systems with a sufficiently high degree of polydispersity , we find that @xmath1 can become smaller than unity , in analogy with observations reported for generalized and complex networks .    </S>",
    "<S> idealized elongated objects such as perfectly rigid cylinders , spherocylinders and prolate spheroids are prototypical models for a wide array of technologically relevant systems that include liquid crystals , nanocomposites based on filamentous fillers as well as fiber - reinforced materials . </S>",
    "<S> percolation phenomena involving dramatic increases in , e.g. , structural rigidity and electrical and thermal conductivities of composites with increasing filler loading are currently of particular interest @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> these increases are caused by the formation of an infinite cluster of in some sense connected particles at the critical loading , i.e. , the percolation threshold .    </S>",
    "<S> it has been established by analytical @xcite and numerical @xcite studies that for dispersions of sufficiently elongated objects of identical size and shape , i.e ,  monodisperse \" objects , the geometric percolation threshold expressed in terms of the critical volume fraction of particles is inversely proportional to the aspect ratio of the filler particles . </S>",
    "<S> this property is exploited in the fabrication of conducting polymeric composites with very low conducting filler contents . </S>",
    "<S> depending on the production processes of the composites , however , the filler particles almost invariably exhibit a pronounced polydispersity in both size and shape @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> although it represents a possible factor behind huge quantitative discrepancies between theory and experiments @xcite , such polydispersity has received relatively little attention in terms of theoretical modeling until fairly recently @xcite , achievement of a theoretical understanding of how the continuum percolation of fibrous fillers is affected by polydispersity is thus key to the controlled design of a large class of composite materials for practical particle size and shape distributions .    </S>",
    "<S> recent analytical results obtained from integral equation methods @xcite and from an heuristic mapping onto a generalized bethe lattice @xcite predict that in the slender rod limit , where the particles have asymptotically large values of the aspect ratio , the volume fraction at the percolation threshold is inversely proportional to the weight average @xmath2 of the rod lengths , where the brackets imply number averages over the distribution of rod lengths @xmath3 . </S>",
    "<S> this letter presents monte carlo ( mc ) results for the percolation threshold of isotropically oriented spherocylindrical particles with length polydispersity and having aspect ratios ranging from @xmath4 to several hundreds . </S>",
    "<S> we show that the percolation threshold of polydisperse , interpenetrable spherocylinders is a nearly universal function of @xmath5 over the entire range of aspect ratios considered . </S>",
    "<S> in addition , the percolation threshold closely follows the predicted @xmath6 behavior even for particles with aspect ratios that are considerably smaller than the slender rod limit , thus generalizing the current theory .    for systems of _ impenetrable _ spherocylinders with fixed @xmath7 , where @xmath8 is the diameter of the hard core </S>",
    "<S> , we show that the percolation threshold is nearly independent of the length distribution . finally , we find that the critical coordination number per particle at the percolation threshold ( denoted @xmath1 ) can be _ smaller _ than unity for polydisperse systems . </S>",
    "<S> although similar observations have been reported for a number of complex networks and in systems of hyperspheres in high - dimensional spaces @xcite , this finding is novel in the context of the continuum percolation of three - dimensional objects .    </S>",
    "<S> we generate isotropically oriented distributions of penetrable rods by randomly placing @xmath9 penetrable shero - cylinders with a distribution of lengths @xmath3 and identical diameter @xmath10 within a cubic box with periodic boundary conditions and side length @xmath11 . as a measure of the concentration of the spherocylinders we shall use the dimensionless density @xmath12 , where @xmath13 is the number - averaged volume of the spherocylinders </S>",
    "<S> , @xmath14 is the mean ( number - averaged ) rod length for a given distribution @xmath15 of lengths , and @xmath16 is the number density of the particles @xcite .    </S>",
    "<S> we consider two spherocylinders as being connected if they overlap geometrically . </S>",
    "<S> the percolation threshold is identified by ascertaining the minimal diameter @xmath17 ( for fixed value of @xmath18 ) for which a cluster of connected particles spans the entire cubic box . </S>",
    "<S> this definition is equivalent to the usual procedure of finding a critical density @xmath19 of spherocylinders with fixed diameter , and has the additional advantages of : ( i ) being computationally more convenient , and ( ii ) allowing a more direct relation to the conductivity @xmath20 of rods through the critical distance approximation @xmath21 , where @xmath22 is the tunneling decay length @xcite .    in the following </S>",
    "<S> we shall use the critical distance @xmath23 , defined as @xmath24 , as our unit of length for polydisperse systems of penetrable spherocylinders . </S>",
    "<S> this quantity corresponds to the critical distance obtained from the second virial approximation formula @xmath25 for the critical concentration of a system of monodisperse spherocylinders with identical lengths @xmath26 chosen to coincide with @xmath27 .     between polydisperse and monodisperse spherocylinders as a function of the fractional occupancy @xmath28 of the longer rods with shorter rod length fixed at @xmath29 in units of @xmath30 ( see text ) . the solid lines represent eq .  . </S>",
    "<S> ( b ) the critical distance ratio @xmath31 in units of @xmath32 calculated from eq .   for @xmath33 as a function of the length @xmath34 of the shorter rods and for selected values of @xmath28 . </S>",
    "<S> ]    to find @xmath17 we employ the clustering method described in ref .  , which allows computation of the spanning probability as a function of the spherocylinder diameter @xmath10 for fixed density @xmath18 ( supplemental material @xcite ) . </S>",
    "<S> figure  [ fig1](a ) shows the results obtained for polydisperse systems with a bimodal length distribution @xmath35 with @xmath29 and @xmath36 , where @xmath37 is the number fraction of long rods . in the figure we display the ratio @xmath31 ( symbols ) of the critical distances for the polydisperse rod system to those for monodisperse systems of spherocylinders with lengths equal to @xmath38 , which for the particular distribution considered corresponds to @xmath39 . </S>",
    "<S> the ratio @xmath31 of the critical distances is systematically reduced by polydispersity and displays a minimum that becomes deeper and moves towards smaller values of @xmath28 as @xmath40 is increased , implying that a small fraction of longer rods can substantially lower the percolation threshold .    </S>",
    "<S> this trend is in full agreement with the theory of ref .   </S>",
    "<S> based on the second virial approximation to the connectedness ornstein - zernike equation , which predicts for @xmath41 : @xmath42 where @xmath2 is the weight - averaged rod lengths . from this equation , and by using @xmath43 for @xmath41 , the critical distance is predicted to follow @xmath44 . </S>",
    "<S> the reduction factor @xmath45 predicted by the theory is thus @xmath46 where the second equality applies for the bimodal length distribution . as shown in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig1](a ) the mc findings for @xmath31 are in semi - quantitative agreement with eq .   </S>",
    "<S> ( solid lines ) , although @xmath31 is consistently slightly smaller than @xmath32 . </S>",
    "<S> this discrepancy could arise from the circumstance that the values of @xmath47 and @xmath34 used in the simulations may be insufficiently large to achieve the slender rod limit , which is a prerequisite for the validity of eq .  . </S>",
    "<S> we examine this issue in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig1](b ) , which shows @xmath48 as a function of @xmath34 ( up to @xmath49 in units of @xmath23 ) for @xmath50 and selected values of @xmath28 . for @xmath51 , our mc results are less than @xmath52% smaller than @xmath53 . </S>",
    "<S> furthermore , for @xmath54 , @xmath48 appears to increase monotonically ( albeit somewhat slowly ) , which may indicate that the slender rod length limit @xmath53 could ultimately be reached ( for any @xmath28 ) only for very long rod lengths .    the mc results shown in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig1 ] and the relatively small deviations from eq .   suggest that , for rods with identical radii , @xmath5 is the key quantity that controls the percolation threshold for mixtures of penetrable spherocylinders . </S>",
    "<S> this is demonstrated in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] where @xmath0 is shown as a function of @xmath55 for various bi - disperse ( open symbols ) and monodisperse ( @xmath56 signs ) systems of spherocylinders ( in the latter case @xmath5 is identical to the unique particle length ) . </S>",
    "<S> results for systems of spherocylinders for which the lengths follow weibull and uniform distributions are shown in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] by filled circles and squares , respectively @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> surprisingly , all of our data collapse onto a single curve over the entire range of @xmath57 , implying that @xmath0 is a quasiuniversal function of @xmath55 independent of the particular distribution considered .    </S>",
    "<S> this finding is rather unexpected because the observed quasiuniversality extends well below the slender rod limit of eq .   </S>",
    "<S> ( solid line ) , which is approached by the mc data to within less than @xmath58 only for @xmath59 . </S>",
    "<S> furthermore , even though eq .   might be expected to apply only asymptotically for @xmath60 , we observe that the data for @xmath61 are well fitted by @xmath62 with @xmath63 and @xmath64 . </S>",
    "<S> the inverse scaling of @xmath0 with @xmath5 thus applies approximatively even for spherocylinders with very modest aspect ratios .     as a function of @xmath55 for monodisperse ( plus symbols ) , bi - disperse ( open symbols ) , weibull ( filled circles ) , and uniform ( filled squares ) distributions of spherocylinder lengths @xcite </S>",
    "<S> . the solid line represents eq .  . </S>",
    "<S> inset : @xmath65 as a function of @xmath66 calculated for mododisperse and bidisperse impenetrable spherocylinders with hard core diameter @xmath8 . </S>",
    "<S> the symbols are the results for both the monodisperse and polydisperse penetrable rods of the main panel . ]    </S>",
    "<S> we have also examined the effects of length polydispersity on the percolation of _ impenetrable _ spherocylinders with identical hard - core diameters @xmath8 . </S>",
    "<S> two impenetrable spherocylinders ( @xmath67 ) are considered to be connected if their surfaces approach closer than @xmath10 . the percolation threshold for a given density @xmath18 of the particles </S>",
    "<S> is identified , as before , by the critical distance @xmath17 . in the slender rod limit </S>",
    "<S> the percolation threshold of impenetrable rods is predicted to follow @xmath68 @xcite , where @xmath69 is the critical volume fraction for the hard - core particles . by noting that eq .   </S>",
    "<S> is the percolation threshold for penetrable rods , and since @xmath43 , we see that for sufficiently elongated rods the percolation relation @xmath70 is predicted to be satisfied by both hard and penetrable rods , independent of their length distribution .    </S>",
    "<S> we have generated by mc simulations equilibrium dispersions of impenetrable spherocylinders with different length ( @xmath3 ) distributions . </S>",
    "<S> the inset of fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] shows @xmath65 as a function of @xmath66 for monodisperse systems with @xmath71 and @xmath72 ( filled symbols ) and for two bidisperse cases with @xmath47 , @xmath34 , and @xmath28 chosen as to give @xmath73 and @xmath72 ( open symbols ) @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> although for computational reasons the rod lengths considered by us are not large enough for our results to fulfill eq .  , we see nevertheless that for a given @xmath7 , @xmath65 is essentially independent of the particular rod length distribution . </S>",
    "<S> furthermore , the calculated @xmath65 values for increasing @xmath7 tend to follow the same functional behavior of the interpenetrable spherocylinders ( signs in the inset of fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] ) @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> this latter feature suggests that for sufficiently large @xmath7 there exists a universal relation of the form @xmath74 , which is expected to reduce to eq .   for @xmath75 and that applies to both penetrable and interpenetrable spherocylinders over a wide range of @xmath66 values .    </S>",
    "<S> although currently there is no theoretical explanation for the quasiuniversal dependence reported in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] , a partial understanding may be achieved by following the method developed in ref .  </S>",
    "<S> @xcite . in this formalism , </S>",
    "<S> applied here for simplicity to penetrable rods , the overall cluster size @xmath76 satisfies @xmath77 where @xmath78 , and @xmath79 is the orientation - averaged connectedness direct correlation function at zero wave vector . within the plausible ansatz @xmath80 @xcite , where the coefficients @xmath81 are assumed to depend only upon the packing fraction </S>",
    "<S> , it is found that for systems with different length distributions but equal values of @xmath55 , @xmath76 diverges at percolation thresholds that differ by @xmath82 for @xmath83 and by @xmath84 for @xmath85 , where @xmath86 is the scaled variance . since the scaled variances for all length distributions considered in this work were always smaller than @xmath87 @xcite , for @xmath88 the expected deviation from universal behavior is thus only @xmath89 , which is consistent with the results of fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] . </S>",
    "<S> although we expect that systems with values of @xmath90 much larger than those considered by us would imply a stronger deviation from universality , @xmath91 is nevertheless representative of the scaled variances observed in several real polydisperse systems of rod - like particles @xcite .    </S>",
    "<S> the quasiuniversal dependence of the percolation threshold upon @xmath5 implies a general _ non - universality _ of the critical coordination number @xmath1 , where @xmath1 denotes the average number of contacts per rod at the percolation threshold . </S>",
    "<S> this is best viewed for the case of randomly placed and oriented overlapping objects for which @xmath92 , where @xmath93 is the excluded volume averaged over the orientations and the rod lengths . given that @xmath0 depends on @xmath55 , while @xmath94 depends on the rod lengths through @xmath95 , we see that mixtures of rods with equal @xmath0 ( _ i.e. _ , equal @xmath5 ) may have rather different @xmath1 if the distribution @xmath15 of the rod lengths is such that @xmath96 .    </S>",
    "<S> figure  [ fig3 ] shows the critical average number of connections per rod calculated from @xmath92 for the same mixtures of penetrable spherocylinders considered in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ] . </S>",
    "<S> we have verified that the configurational average of the connection per rods at @xmath17 coincides with the excluded volume formula , as expected . </S>",
    "<S> we see that in general , @xmath1 is sensitive to the extent of polydispersity , although in the limit @xmath97 it can be expected that @xmath1 should coincide with the result for identical , overlapping spheres , namely @xmath98 @xcite . in particular , @xmath1 is always larger than unity and approaches @xmath99 asymptotically in the slender rod limit for monodisperse systems . </S>",
    "<S> in contrast , for distributions with sufficiently large values of the variance and of @xmath55 , polydisperse systems of rods may display fewer than one connection per particle at the threshold , _ </S>",
    "<S> i.e. _ , @xmath100 .     as a function of @xmath55 for polydisperse and monodisperse spherocylinders . </S>",
    "<S> the symbols have the same meaning as in the main panel of fig .  [ fig2 ] . ]    </S>",
    "<S> this latter feature is somewhat novel since the continuum percolation of objects randomly dispersed in a three dimensional space is usually characterized by the condition @xmath101 @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> indeed , to the best of our knowledge , percolation occurring with @xmath102 has been reported only for penetrable identical hyperspheres in spaces of dimensionality exceeding @xmath103 @xcite and in random or complex networks that are _ not _ embedded in a physical space . </S>",
    "<S> for example , given an uncorrelated network with nodes having a distribution of coordination numbers @xmath104 , upon random removal of nodes the network becomes disconnected at a critical node occupation probability @xmath105 @xcite , which results from the irrelevance of closed loops @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> the critical coordination number @xmath106 is thus @xmath107 which can be smaller than unity when the node degree distribution is such that @xmath108 .    </S>",
    "<S> the results of fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig3 ] that show that polydisperse rod mixtures may display @xmath102 suggest that these systems may relate to such classes of generalized graphs that can exhibit the same feature @xcite . indeed , as shown in ref .  , </S>",
    "<S> eq .   </S>",
    "<S> is also the critical coordination number of a generalized bethe lattice that by construction lacks closed loops . </S>",
    "<S> hence , by applying the mapping @xmath109 , @xmath110 formulated for polydisperse slender rods in ref .  , we find @xmath111 which is qualitatively consistent with the behavior of @xmath1 seen in fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig3 ] . a physical explanation for the observation that @xmath112 for sufficiently polydisperse rod systems is provided by the fact that the percolating cluster is predominantly comprised of the longer rods in the system , and the shorter rods have a greater likelihood of being isolated @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> an interesting corollary arising from this interpretation is that , as in generalized random networks where targeted removal of highly connected nodes enhances the percolation threshold @xcite , preferential removal of the longer rods from the system may lead to similar enhancement of the critical concentration .    in conclusion , we have studied by mc simulations the effects of length polydispersity on the percolation threshold of penetrable spherocylinders . </S>",
    "<S> we find a quasiuniversal dependence of the percolation threshold on @xmath5 that extends well below the slender rod limit considered in refs .  </S>",
    "<S> [ ] . for systems of impenetrable spherocylinders we find that universality is fulfilled for a given @xmath7 , where @xmath8 is the hard - core diameter . </S>",
    "<S> the predicted quasiuniversality could be tested by experiments in systems of conducting fibrous fillers by altering the distribution of the rod lengths , e.g. , by sonication , and measuring the resulting change in the percolation threshold . </S>",
    "<S> furthermore we have demonstrated that the average number of connections per rod at the percolation threshold can be smaller than unity for random distributions of rods that are sufficiently slender and polydisperse . </S>",
    "<S> this finding reveals an intriguing analogy with the case of random percolation in complex networks .    </S>",

    "<S> the volume fraction @xmath113 for randomly placed penetrable spherocylinders is related to @xmath114 through @xmath115 . </S>",

    "<S> b * 83 * , 064203 ( 2011 ) .    </S>",
    "<S> see supplemental material for more details on the calculation of the spanning probabilities and on the rod length distributions used in our work .    </S>",
    "<S> the systems with weibull distribution have been generated by considering rods with lengths @xmath118 ( @xmath119 ) distributed according to the discretized weibull probability function @xmath120-\\exp[-(l_{i+1}/\\lambda)/^k]$ ] with @xmath121 and @xmath122 , @xmath123 , @xmath124 , and @xmath125 . </S>",
    "<S> uniform distributions of rods have been constructed from @xmath126 for @xmath127 and @xmath128 otherwise , with @xmath129 and @xmath130 , @xmath131 , @xmath72 , and @xmath132 .    </S>",
    "<S> when @xmath65 is plotted as a function of @xmath66 , the system of penetrable rods displays a ( quasi-)independence on the length distribution similar to that observed from the @xmath0 versus @xmath55 plot of the main panel of fig .  </S>",
    "<S> [ fig2 ]    the form of this ansatz is suggested by dimensional considerations and by the fact that the direct correlation function is a local quantity . </S>",
    "<S> the coefficients @xmath133 , @xmath134 , and @xmath135 represent respectively the contributions arising from cylinder - cylinder , cylinder - cap , and cap - cap correlations . </S>",
    "<S> for @xmath136 they reduce to the second virial approximation @xmath137 , @xmath138 , and @xmath139 .    </S>",
